natural solution: The shaded area is equal to the area of the square minus the area of the four circles. Since the side length of the square is $20$ inches, the radius of the circles is $20/4 = 5$ inches. The square has area $20^2 = 400$ square inches, and each circle has area $5^2 \pi = 25\pi$ square inches, so the shaded area, in square inches, is equal to \[400 - 4 \cdot 25\pi = \boxed{400 - 100\pi}.\]

theorem
fixes s :: real and c :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "s = 20 * 20"
and h1 : "\<forall> r. c r = pi * r * r"
and h2 : "4 * c 10 = 400 * pi"
shows  "s - 4 * c 10 = 400 - 100 * pi"

(* ### Problem

 ### Proof

The square has area $20^2 = 400$ square inches, and each circle has area $5^2 \pi = 25\pi$ square inches, so the shaded area, in square inches, is equal to \[400 - 4 \cdot 25\pi = \boxed{400 - 100\pi}.\]

fixes s :: real and c :: "real \<Rightarrow> real"
assumes h0 : "s = 20 * 20"
and h1 : "\<forall> r. c r = pi * r * r"
and h2 : "4 * c 10 = 400 * pi"
shows  "s - 4 * c 10 = 400 - 100 * pi"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
